channel.title: The ReadME Project
channel.description: The ReadME Project amplifies the voices of the open source community: the maintainers, developers, and teams whose contributions move the world forward every day.

item.title: Formatters, linters, and compilers: Oh my!
item.description: Discover the essentials of static analysis tools in JavaScript and TypeScript, and unlock the power of formatters, linters, and type checkers for improved code quality and error prevention.

item.title: The case for using Rust in MLOps
item.description: Rust’s performance, package management, and other features make it a strong alternative to Python for MLOps, especially used in conjunction with GitHub Copilot.

item.title: Accelerate test-driven development with AI
item.description: Test-Driven Development (TDD) involves writing tests, then writing the code to satisfy those tests. The process gives developers faster feedback on the quality of the software design. GitHub Copilot helps write the tests and the code, further accelerating the entire process.

item.title: Harness the power of generative AI for software development
item.description: Large language models and generative AI can boost developers’ productivity and efficiency, but it helps to understand prompt engineering. While AI can appear human, writing to it like a human can be counterproductive. Learn how to best craft your query.

item.title: Coding accessibility: Disability as catalyst for creativity
item.description: When faced with accessibility barriers, developer Paul Chiou gets creative, building custom hardware interfaces and innovative software solutions for himself and others. Read how Chiou works to increase access for all.

item.title: How ‘open’ should your open source be?
item.description: Open source isn’t one size fits all. Some is open, some closed, and most is in-between. From Litestream to Lua to Prometheus and more, maintainers explain their reasons for where they lie on the spectrum from open to closed, and why there’s more to contributions than code.

item.title: Champion accessibility to unleash untapped potential
item.description: Dr. Annalu Waller, rehabilitation engineer and Professor of Human Communication Technologies at Dundee University, shares her path to overcoming barriers and empowering others to reach their full potential.

item.title: Safer GitHub administration through IssueOps
item.description: How to use GitHub Actions to automatically promote and demote repository admins, just like using sudo to control permissions in Linux.

item.title: Twitch: A game changer for developers
item.description: Johanna Pirker says the gaming world has something to offer businesses, educators, and developers. Virtual worlds provide a sense of togetherness that traditional business software like Zoom doesn’t, and Pirker chooses Twitch for teaching and coding online, and more.

item.title: Junior to senior: An action plan for engineering career success
item.description: A guide providing actionable tips on how to transition from a junior to senior software engineer. Learn the essential technical competencies and communication skills needed to succeed, including the importance of business domain comprehension and effective documentation.

item.title: Simplifying developer onboarding with a few clicks
item.description: Learn how Duolingo migrated to GitHub Codespaces, streamlining their software development process. Discover the benefits of remote development and how to securely grant access to private resources.

item.title: Open source is fueling the future of nuclear physics
item.description: A look at the open source artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and high performance computing (HPC) tools used in the nuclear fusion ignition breakthrough at Lawerence Livermore Labs.

item.title: Putting the African open source community on the map
item.description: Once indifferent about computers, Ruth Ikegah put in the time, patience, and work to become a force for change in open source, and is now connecting other Africans with the resources they need to succeed, too.

item.title: How to put the plus in ‘staff+’ engineer
item.description: Whether you’re already a staff+ engineer or you’re looking to advance, here’s how to be a force multiplier for your teams and organization

item.title: Find edge case errors in your code base
item.description: GitHub Copilot not only increases developer efficiency and reduces boilerplate code, it can help find edge case errors in your code base—just ask HubSpot software engineer Claudio Wunder.

item.title: From gaming with your eyes to coding with AI: New frontiers for accessibility
item.description: Open source offers developers with disabilities the flexibility needed to participate and collaborate. Their contributions and involvement in the research, design, and development of software are integral to making technology accessible to all.

item.title: Invite the critics and keep learning
item.description: When Windows 11 debuted with limited access, @blueedgetechno created a *very* convincing clone. Hear why he has a female avatar, maintains a growth mindset, and more on The ReadME Project:

item.title: The modern web’s underrated powerhouse
item.description: CSS has come a long way, but it still doesn’t get the attention JavaScript does. @klintron explains why you might want to give CSS another look:

item.title: Out of the slums and into open source
item.description: From a slum in India to a Google Developer Expert in Germany, @SantoshYadavDev shares how he leveraged software development as a path out of poverty in The ReadME Project:

item.title: What’s in a name? Moving GitOps beyond buzzword
item.description: Unlike many other technical portmanteaus, “GitOps” is worth defining, says @rwwmike, and here’s why:

item.title: Raising the bar for open source standards
item.description: After seeing first-hand how stifling inaccessibility is, Leonardo strives to create an open source world where everyone can seamlessly participate. He shares his full story on The ReadME Project:

item.title: What we can learn from vintage computing
item.description: The “old ways” are actually a prime opportunity to learn, escape today’s exhausting digital environments, and get inspired

item.title: Building super fans through genuine human connections
item.description: She never considered tech as a potential career path, but @janaboruta leveraged her empathy to successfully build open source communities of super fans. Her full story, now on The ReadME Project:

item.title: Marie Kondo your software stack with open source
item.description: Minimalism in software development is not only a desirable design goal—but also a survival strategy. @rwwmike explains how to Marie Kondo your software stack:

item.title: The purest form of collaboration
item.description: Fueled by the versatility of computer science, @avi_press learned by doing, then started a company to help clear the roadblocks he ran into. Get his full story on The ReadME Project:

item.title: Open source is democratizing video game development
item.description: The democratization of open source game development, from Adobe Flash to game jams and beyond:

item.title: (Virtual) reality check
item.description: Growing up, @JoeyPrink didn’t know what computer science meant. Now she’s a TU Graz Grad and MIT alum, Forbes 30 Under 30 alum, and assistant professor prioritizing inclusive virtual spaces. Read more on The ReadME Project:

item.title: Building the future of the command line
item.description: The command line has come a long way since its days as a blinking cursor on a blank screen. @klintron explain how open source is making it both more powerful and more user-friendly:

item.title: Sometimes they say yes
item.description: In the past 12 months, @aarondfrancis changed his life by bypassing fear and embracing risk. Now, he’s working his dream job @tuple. Get his full story on The ReadME Project:

item.title: Stewards of code, stewards of each other
item.description: Supporting and sharing different perspectives and opinions is foundational to @KaraAJC, and imperative for a healthy and inclusive OSS community:
